title: Frustration at speed of repairs to Kuala Lumpur's klia2 'sinking' terminal
text:
Frustration at speed of repairs to Kuala Lumpur's klia2 'sinking' terminal MICHAEL DALY Last updated 15:02, July 28 2015 SAMSUL SAID/Reuters 
A staff member stands near an information counter at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA2). 
Kuala Lumpur's new budget passenger airport terminal is "sinking" and airlines are raising concerns about passenger safety and aircraft damage. 
AirAsia, the terminal's biggest user, told reporters cracks in the taxiway and ponding could cause flight delays and increase wear and tear on planes, as well as posing potential safety risks. 
Take-offs and landings were unaffected and operator Malaysia Airports Holdings had done some partial resurfacing, but a permanent solution was needed, AirAsia chief executive Aireen Omar said. "The airport is still sinking" Omar added. Tony Fernandes, group chief executive of AirAsia, took to Twitter to vent his frustration: Is this to be expected?8 hour delay due to plane slipping of chocks . The board has to take responsibility pic.twitter.com/X7EAt3jvft — Tony Fernandes (@tonyfernandes) July 27, 2015 sad that my ceo @aireenomar has to waste her time keep going to malaysia airports to sort something that should never have happened. — Tony Fernandes (@tonyfernandes) July 27, 2015 The response from malaysia airports that this is to be expected is ridiculous.The board and management need a strong hard look at themselves — Tony Fernandes (@tonyfernandes) July 27, 2015 
Malaysia Airports told Bloomberg the settling had been anticipated. Problem areas were being patched and resurfaced and polyurethane was being injected under the ground. 
A concrete slab to be ready by April would provide a more permanent solution. 
Construction started in 2009 on the new terminal, which is known as KLIA2 and is about 2km from Kuala Lumpur International Airport and about 50km from Kuala Lumpur, the Malaysian capital. 
Originally scheduled to be finished by June 2013, the 257,000sq m KLIA2, which can cater for 45 million passengers a year, was officially opened in May 2014. Construction costs increased from the original budget of 1.6 billion ringgit (NZ$633m) to 4b ringgit. 
Bloomberg noted KLIA2 was not the only aviation facility in Asia to have problems. 
Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi airport, built on a reclaimed swamp, had cracks in taxiways and runways and faulty baggage-scanning machines. Some taxiways had to be closed for repair and the old airport was reopened to alleviate congestion. 
In Japan, Osaka's Kansai International Airport was found to be sinking. It was opened in 1994, after taking nearly eight years to build on a manmade island at a cost of 1.43 trillion yen (NZ$17.5b). Ad Feedback 
The Malaysian aviation industry also took two severe blows with two plane crashes in 2014 - Malaysia Airlines flights MH370 and MH17. 
"Since MH370, a lot of shortcomings have been found" in Malaysia's aviation infrastructure, Shukor Yusof, founder of Singapore-based consultancy Endau Analytics, told Bloomberg. 
Mark D Martin, chief executive of Dubai-based Martin Consulting said aggressive steps were needed to improve aviation standards in Asia. 
Last December, Malaysia's Transport Ministry set up a five-member audit committee to investigate the sinking and ponding problems at KLIA2. - Stuff
